commentBody:
The three long answers in the middle are a tragedy in three parts of a gambler down on their luck

PLAY IT COOL
DOUBLE OR NOTHING
ROCK BOTTOM

Very evocative. 

The stacks in the top and bottom tell a story too. 

Top stack: two friends preparing to go out
“Easy TIGER, you might want to DIAL IT BACK.”
“What, you want me to be ANTISOCIAL?”
“No, I’m just saying BARBIECORE might be a bit much for a trip to the LONDON ZOO.”

And the bottom tells the story of an agreeable quarterback open to suggestions from his coach on how to speed up the game.
METOO was 2006?
Loved it
A shockingly easy Friday.  I wasn't rushing, and finished in half my average time.  I hope Saturday's puzzle puts up more of a fight.
Not only a fun and clever puzzle, but that’s three days in a row for me with almost the exact same times. I just know Saturday’s going to be a 40-minute debacle to make up for this.

Some fun clues in this one, like present day attire for SANTASUIT and they help you get off the lot for AUTOLOANS.  It came together pretty quickly for a Friday.

I was happy to see Marilyn McCoo get some love in the puzzle.  Her smooth as silk vocals with the Fifth Dimension were some of the high points of sixties soul.  Yet somehow she never gets mentioned when the great female soul singers get discussed or listed.  Maybe that’s because she’s deemed more pop than soul, but it seems like an injustice to me.  Her version of One Less Bell To Answer is as soulful as they come.
I'm still looking for the dupe mentioned in the column.
I'm still not understanding TOE. Is it just a toe ring? Confused...
Wasn't familiar with BARBIECORE, but I still managed to guess it on my first go around. 11 minutes, nice and easy

Wonderful puzzle.

I laughed, I cried.  It became a part of me.
Alas, London no longer considers itself part of Europe :-(
I done did this puzz
That was a very very breezy Friday.  Thank you.
Like Weds difficulty

Congratulations on your NYT debut, Mr. Davis! The grid is full of lively and fresh answers. Many of the clues feel fresh, too (e.g. YASIR, LONDON ZOO, GUAM and FACTS. 

Thanks, gents!
help please 9 down charge? care?

"Whoa! Easy there, buddy!"

Easier read than done.
Harder to fill than some.
Was scratchin my head like a porch hound with September fleas. After 40 mins, called calf rope with TWO little squares amiss - "plants" shore had to be SITES, as in factories.

Funny how the old bean can persuade you that wrong fill is good fill, till it ain't.

Great Friday solve!

Kind of an easy puzzle?  SUREWHYNOT.  We deserved a break.  No complaints here, and this one was fun.  
 
Lots of amusing clues tucked in all through the grid:  Discretely fill in, in a way;  Present day attire?  Well pitched—very cool indeed.

Thank you, Greg and Glenn, I needed that.

Zipped through this puzzle. Nearly every long entry I filled in without crosses was correct, and the few proper names were ones I knew right away. Either I was on the same wavelength as the constructor or somehow Wednesday and Friday got switched. I'm the right age to remember Marilyn McCoo as the host of Solid Gold. For the youngsters (including myself!), I only learned last year that she was a member of The 5th Dimension in the 60s and 70s. https://youtu.be/vbCH5lnZ6sA?si=pPsdBDGm4crLFaVI TIL talc is used in chewing gum, but you know what else most modern chewing gum is made from? PLASTIC. Most chewing gum manufacturers stopped using natural chicle (rubber) in favor of synthetic, petroleum-based rubber (i.e. plastic) decades ago. https://petroleumservicecompany.com/blog/petroleum-product-of-the-week-chewing-gum/ There is still natural chewing gum, but to me, it's not great. And gum gives me a headache anyway. No thanks.

One definition of an ANTISOCIAL person: 

Someone who, seeing
“garlic rich topping” and - - OLI 
thought for even 3 milliseconds that could be 
E COLI.

I really wanted for 1A to be "simmer down." And it fit. I'm glad I waited for the crosses. 

TIL Guam's flag, with its little sailboat and palm tree. I'm pretty sure I'll never forget it, what with it being so darned cute.

This was overall a very enjoyable puzzle and I thank you, Mr. Snitkin and Mr. Davis. The two of you should definitely pair up on another one!
What is the “dupe” that is being referred to in the intro to today’s Wordplay? #confused

Got stuck on SOW instead of SOD which made me have to hunt for the “wrong letter” at the end. I knew WISC didn’t make any sense, but hey on a Friday who knows. Needed google to get me past that, otherwise no hints!
Nice cluing. Oblique but precise.
I love the puzzles where after 7 minutes it looks totally hopeless and after 13 (ok, 13:05 in this case) it's totally done.
Delightful puzzle! Loved AUTOLOANS, SANTASUIT, and ONKEY. Super fun - I have a 50/50 solve rate for Fridays so it’s nice to get this one solved!

Interesting clueing for Isis, as it invokes her later, Hellenized tradition. Her original Egyptian name translates literally as She of the Throne and was pronounced something like Ahs(e)t, with Ahs meaning throne, plus the feminizing -t. The Greeks dropped the -t and added the Greek feminizing -is, et voilà! Isis was born. And from the sibling-mother of Osiris, her myth eventually became much more universal. Here is Apuleius having her introduce herself in 2nd c. CE:  

“I am Nature, the universal Mother, mistress of all the elements, primordial child of Time, sovereign of all things spiritual, queen of the dead, queen also of the immortals, the single manifestation of all gods and goddesses that are. (…)

Though I am worshipped in many aspects, known by countless names, and propitiated with all manner of different rites, yet the whole round earth venerates me. The primeval Phrygians call me Pessinuntica, Mother of the Gods; the Athenians (…) call me Cecropian Artemis; for the islanders of Cyprus, I am Paphian Aphrodite; for the archers of Crete, I am Dictynna; for the trilingual Sicilians, Stygian Proserpine; and for the Eleusinians, their ancient Demeter.

Some know me as Juno, some as Bellona of the Battles; others as Hecate; others again as Rhamnusia. But (…) the Egyptians, who excel in ancient learning and worship me with ceremonies proper to my godhead, call me by my true name: Queen Isis.”
Too many unknowns for me to finish without lookups. That's been the theme of this week's puzzles for me.
Back when PDAs were a thing, was Android a thing?  Or am I not getting the context?
Loved it. I was totally on the constructors' wavelength. My Friday PB!

AMI crazy, or was that was a Friday personal best by a very, very wide margin?

Spoiler alert: I'm not crazy! 

Wow, I flew through it and I wasn't even trying to. I don't aim for speed and I even forgot to turn off my clock when I went to pour myself a little spot of...  Dang!

But, it was a lot of fun and had a lot of fresh and lively entries in it I thought. A handful of things I didn't know offhand, but the crosses were incredibly kind. I'm still in shock at my time.

I thought they'll leave it to Beaver clue for DAM and the present day clue for SANTASUIT were especially cute.

I'm happy that I don't chew gum and I think I might have to make my husband stop. 

No idea why I knew the GUAM answer immediately. It's probably because I have plans geography game, but I haven't really gotten to the flag level yet. 

Anyhow, fun outing!

Also, I SAY, I really wish the box didn't default to being checked. My personal email box is already where all things go to die, I don't need anymore in it and I keep forgetting to uncheck it because I used to just have it constantly unchecked.
Thought it was going to be a quickie, but then spent a ton of time stuck in the NW.

Excellent puzzle, but I have to note that “Vegas hot spot” is an unfortunate clue for the MGM Hotel. In 1980, the former MGM Grand was the site of a terrible fire, the worst disaster in Nevada history and the third worst hotel fire in US history.
What’s with the holes up top? Someone please explain!

I was very proud of myself for knowing that the Schönbrunn Zoo in Vienna is the oldest zoo in the world and happily put VIENNA ZOO as the answer to 32D. Not sure why, since that’s not even the zoo’s name! Alas, my overconfidence threw me off in that whole section. Once I (begrudgingly) corrected my mistake, I breezed through. Nice puzzle.

Wait, hasn’t talc been linked to cancer? Isn’t that the reason for the long court battle over baby powder? And it’s in GUM? I don’t know what to think, other than I’m glad I’ve never been a gum chewer.

This one started slow for me, but then some cracks appeared and gave me a way in. My biggest holdup was being certain that the Great Mother goddess had to be Gaia. The fact that I already had the third letter in place (the “I” from BARBIECORE) didn’t help.

GAIA for ISIS and GDAY for ISAY really held me back 😆

Today years old, I found out TAR is (or hopefully was) an additive in gum. SUREWHYNOT. IMO, I fear another class action lawsuit may be on the way.

Good grid. Interesting without being too chewy.

I guessed LONDON ZOO without having ever been, though I did once stay overnight in a hotel overlooking Regents Park, the home of said zoo. It was surreal to hear the lions roaring while in bed in the middle of London! 

Wasted 5 minutes looking for my error. Turns out the divine Ms Angelou was talking about FACTS, not FAtTS. It’s CZAR not tZAR. Duh.

Glad I’m not a gum chewer. Also, my instinctive answer to ‘ring bearer’ will always be Frodo.

I thought I was so smart as I immediately wrote in mooS for [Low notes], but I was quickly disabused of that notion.

Breezy Friday with some lively cluing.  NO FAIR crossing FIGHTS DIRTY was a nice touch.

No sarcasm today:
Here's the Hilliard Ensemble--who always sing ON KEY--reminding us to make AMENDs, because, hey, we're dust, and will return to dust. (Sorry, no video save the album cover, or text/translation).

One of my favorite pieces of Renaissance choral polyphony, and, for Catholics, particularly appropriate for today, Good Friday.
Up here, north of the 49th parallel, nowadays we call 13-Down a Canadiana.  Elbows up!

This isn’t a complaint about the puzzle, which I enjoyed. BARBIE CORE, which I got pretty quickly, makes me wonder whether the -core suffix will be played out soon or will hang around forever, like -gate, despite being tiresome and meaningless.
I did see a mini-theme in the puzzle: double or nothing—play, play, Barbie, doll, talc, rock, accelerate, dial it back.
Normally, Friday solves takes me about 15 minutes. I'm already going on 15 and only about halfway done. Loving this.
sneaky tricky funny!

Fun breezy Friday, a PB for me. I find it really fun when I can get a long entry right off the bat with no crosses. LIBERTYBELL was that for me today. Several fun long entries - I got a kick out of FIGHTSDIRTY and a chuckle out of ACCELERATE. ALTER was a true groaner. 

I guess the editors heard you all complaining on Wednesday that the puzzle was too hard, and gave us a Wednesday level on Friday in response. 

Happy Friday, everyone!

This, to me, was about the bigs, those answers of eight letters or more.  Oh, how they shined today.  That shine is what vivifies a puzzle, makes it compelling, enthralls, excites.  This grid design (never before seen in the Times puzzle) allowed for a soaring 15 bigs.

Look at them!  My favorites?  DIAL IT BACK, PLAY IT COOL, DOUBLE OR NOTHING, ROCK BOTTOM, PLAY ACTION, SURE WHY NOT, AMERICANO, FIGHTS DIRTY.  

All these in one box!  And they are placed in a solid, clean, wince-free set of answers.  

Plus, sweet serendipities. A no-vowel palindrome (MGM) in the box with an all-vowel palindrome (EYE).  COO crossing COO in the middle.  Four double-O’s.  LOB and LOBOS (Hi, @Beth!)

Greg, high props on your grid design and fill-in.  Glenn, congratulations on your debut and the role you played in the delightful cluing.  Thank you both for this spirited endeavor -- what a springboard for the day!
A relatively easy Friday(close to my record time) but I’m not complaining.

My filling the puzzle sort of snowballed as I completed the NE corner, with the rest of the puzzle yet to be filled.  Took 37% less time than average.  Was slowed down a bit with the middle of the top three rows.

My finish time suggests this was on the easy side, but really fresh. The NE killed me for a time: couldn't remember Naomi's last name, and held on to pad for 7D for way too long.

Charge can mean so many different verbs and nouns. I needed some crosses to finish that one.
I'm not fully trained in the use of CORE, but I'll get there.

The wisdom of the jungle - 
using your stripes to obscure your own truth,
the facts of tooth and claw.
Is that fighting dirty?

A very fast solve.
Odd...puzzles got easier as the week progressed. I say, "Giddy-up!!!"
Same experience as others.  Started out with next to "nuttin" until the bell rang and worked out from the SW.  Nicely done and thanks.

A satisfying and clever Friday solve. I feel compelled to say, however, that my OY's are anything but faux. An OY is a heartfelt expression of despair and one I find myself using with increasing frequency these days.
First pass through brought out a really meaningful "OY!" But from there things settled down and I even discovered that Barbiecore is a thing!
Loved the puzzle today, very clever. Great job!
I wanted "Present-day attire?" to be Birthday SUIT.  Yes, I know it doesn't fit, but I still like my answer better than the correct one.

I'm proud of myself today for getting the "SANTA SUIT" pun with very few crosses. 

Also, I find it very hard to believe "PLAY ACTION" is a compelling enough phrase to warrant a duplicate word
For my current crossword puzzle solving ability, this was right in my wheelhouse. No lookups. So IMO a perfect Friday Puzzle. Huzzah!

The only one I was not sure of was the answer to "charge." Are we talking about someone in our care being our charge? I am still a bit confounded by that one (not having been intimately familiar with Barbie Core). Otherwise, 8:47 for a Friday -- not bad! Fun puzzle.
Oy! Antisocial rock bottom Czar fights dirty. Why not? Facts!

One thing I've learned from reading the Wordplay column is to slow down, take a breath, and take a sip of coffee whenever I see a ? in a clue. Going at the usual solve-speed always means I'll make an error. But the ? means something's a-foot. (Did I need that hyphen? I'll look that up later.)

That extra second won me SANTASUIT, which was a nice chuckle. TOE filled itself in, thank heavens, because I don't think I'd have gotten that on my own. Some of the longer fills were less difficult than I expected just because they were fun. ACCELERATE reminded me of a time, about 52 years ago, when my then-fiance and I were driving very late (about 3 or 4 a.m.) back home from somewhere on Long Island (maybe Long Beach?) on a deserted highway, and he chose to, ahem, ignore a light. 

When the only-still-awake cop pulled us over, I told him "say you sneezed" (hey, I was still a kid) and that's what he did. I swear the cop had to stifle a laugh. Either that, or the friend-of-the-police thing he carried in his wallet with his license got us off with a warning, and he drove responsibly after that. 

Greg and Glenn, thanks for a fun start to my Friday!
Personally, I think the answer to "They help you get off a lot" should have been VIBRATORS.

INAPT?
For the longest time I had Gaia instead of ISIS

For 21D I had SOW, which still fits the clue. And 30A being DISC?! That's a truly awful and useless clue, so I got stuck with WISC, which I know didn't make sense. But not any less sense than DISC being the answer. A throat lozenge would be any sucking candy shape. Terrible, just terrible.
That's not what antisocial means
never been to the london zoo, but I bet it's got cool cats

LONDON and TIGER reminded me of William Blake, but his poems are not that forum-friendly.  So DOUBLE OR NOTHING led me to Wislawa Szymborska “Nothing Twice,” which begins with a wallop:

Nothing can ever happen twice.
In consequence, the sorry fact is
that we arrive here improvised
and leave without the chance to practice.

Even if there is no one dumber,
if you’re the planet’s biggest dunce,
you can’t repeat the class in summer:
this course is only offered once.

It could end as she ended another poem, “Love at First Sight:

Every beginning
is only a sequel, after all,
and the book of events
is always open halfway through.

Meh--I'll take the Fail.  BARBIE CODE? COKE? COPE? COVE?  Whatever.  It's still ridiculous.  
McCOO and TECA (still no clue on the latter) and "What the..." for 65A....which turned out to be sloppy handwriting.... I thought it was an A, which explains TECA--the word that wasn't.  

So, two wrong letters.  It would have been worse if not for the crossings,   The 2007 book/author entry/clue were particularly indefensible, even if it did get the constructors out of a tight spot.  Good spot for a German-language clue.  (I always got a chuckle out of the Cabinet member named KLEINdienst...._)
Sorry, didn't care for the puzzle.

Boy, having SOW for 21D leaving me WISC for 30A turned into a real stumper. Funnily enough, I'd thought of SOD early in the solve, but then filled in SOW as I decided it was a much better pairing with the clue. Coming back to the lozenge later, I just had no idea.

All in all a fun solve!

This one whizzed right along for me, and might have been a PB except for the NW corner, which caused a little stumbling. Gaia, aorti, BARBIEchic were all in there first. Then ended up with all A's and I's trying to fill in 15A. 
Call me ANTISOCIAL, but I'm really just more of a solitary person. I'd prefer if one didn't TAR me with the same brush.😊
As a decaf drinker who has been asked “Is Americano ok?” countless times in coffee shops and reluctantly said “Yes”, I heartily concur with the clue given for 13D. Fun puzzle overall!

A fun fill! I copped some flak on Wednesday for saying "I'm all for a challenge" but thought the clues on that puzzle were mean spirited - this is a great example of a challenge where patience and lateral thinking will yield answers.

(still not over PTUI :)
A little disappointed that the early week puzzles have been trickier than the late week ones so far but this was still a fun fill. LIBERTYBELL was a gimme.

I had a good laugh when I thought that 7D was going to be some variation of a Birthday Suit.
But barely nothing would fit.

Great Puzzle!

Correction:

I had a good laugh when I thought that 12D was going to be some variation of a Birthday Suit.
But barely nothing would fit.

Great Puzzle!

Got it in decent time and it was a fun puzzle, but my uncaffeinated brain is still confused by a couple of the smaller downs.

LOB?  If it was like an easy baseball pitch, then it would be a 'pre smash-hit' not a 'pre-smash hit' Or does it refer to something else entirely?

And LAW?   One law covers all estates? Maybe I'm overthinking it?
Wait, which entries are repeated in different contexts (alluded to in the blog)?

Strands Thread.  No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button:


Strands #411
“On the board”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵

I believe a debut by Joel Fagliano?  Guess he is atoning for all the tough Mini's.
PDA ?

Not as delightful as yesterday but still fine.
I completely accept that there will be some clues I don't know and can't guess - looking at Marilyn MCCOO and LOBOS - but as long as there are not too many, I'll enjoy the crossword. 

How many is how many is a moot point (I got 'moot' from Law and Order, my favourite US programme).

I wonder what tomorrow will bring?
Finished exactly at my average time. I’m satisfied!

-CORE as a vide or trend?  WTH?

On the other hand I had no trouble with 10D because I just happen to be reading The Shock Doctrine.

Trouble sleeping, so I got up and worked through the "hard-mode" version. Just finished the "easy-mode" at lunchtime.
First time I've done it this way. Mostly I just stick to the easy mode.
I enjoyed it both times!

I'm all upside down this week. My time today was only a third of the time I spent on yesterday's. It didn't feel fast as I was doing it, though. And I did pause a moment before entering that final P, wondering whether this was one of those pushing-the-rules times or whether I'd missed something.

The earlier P in the puzzle brought to mind a postcard we sold where I worked at the time, "The Data Loss Bereavement Kit." I could relate. I knew someone who either lost his PDA or it lost itself, and he was in shock when he realized he had absolutely no idea what his schedule was for the week, or month. He was a UU minister and I'll bet he lost some good sermon notes, too.

When I restarted this morning, I still had 15 blank squares and a ton of Pencil-ed in ones; also, a lot of my fills didn't make sense and were likely wrong, such as 31D, PDA, for "Droid." I was finally forced to turn to the column, which kindly gave me the R for the 9D/17A cross.

Reading further, I found I needed to change my 18A, "Low notes," from BASS to ONES. With that I was able to fill in all but seven of my still blank squares, three in 11A, three in 16A, and one in 30A, where I have WIS_, with a Pencil-ed W.

No time to continue now, so I will postpone giving up or reading the Comments until I won't be allowed to keep trying (all day?). It won't be a true five-day streak with my Column peek, but the app won't know, and it would be fun to see it say I should turn it into a six-dayer tonight.
This was fun!
Could someone explain  9D? I'm puzzled. Thanks!
I got stuck on Yaser/Tre. Pretty sure both E and I work there. Very frustrating.
Enjoyed the puzzle. Southwest corner was my last spot to solve. Some terrific misdirections. I’m still trying to find the dupe on the grid that Deb mentions. Can someone put me out of my misery?
A little quick (10m33s), but fun.
Once again, I'm begging for there to be proper usage of asocial/antisocial. Antisocial typically involves intent and actively being against. Asocial means more withdrawn, quiet, solitary.

This was so much fun! Had BarbieLove for too long. Bcc just didn’t click today.
Happy weekend! Thanks for such a good one today.

Late to the party. Did this one early this morning but then had a busy day. Anyway... not all that easy for me, of course. More than a couple of answers that I would never have connected to the clues. Had to cheat a bit and then work the crosses. Ended up being an enjoyable workout. Puzzle find today: A Monday from April 7, 2014 by Douglas Taillon. Four theme answers - two across and two down: DOUBLEORNOTHING TWINENGINEPLANE SECONDHELPING GOODYTWOSHOES Thought that was kind of cute. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/7/2014&g=16&d=A ...

The NW had me stumped for awhile. I knew it was BARBIE something, but CHIC refused to work, and that's about all I had up there. I almost did a lookup on the author, but then TOE popped into my mind and things began to fall into place after that, as they inevitably do. Thanks for the fun!

Enjoyable puzzle, but I'm not sure I understand 49A:

"Leave it to beaver?" = DAM

1. ? indicates tricky/pause for a minute
2. "beaver" is in the clue

1+2 = tricky 3-letter answer with "beaver" in the clue, so I got the answer easily, but I didn't get my usual satisfaction from a "?" clue. I don't understand how "leave it to beaver" actually solves as DAM.

Are we to infer that if we need a dam, we should wait around for a beaver to build it? That seems strained.

Kind of the same as the Droid/PDA issue. I got both answers; I'm just not sure I "got" them.

51 down: Social movement introduced in 2006.

I'm pretty sure Me Too started in 2017, not 2006.
Based on my solve times and my feeling while doing the puzzles, Wednesday and Friday got switched. Today felt very easy, whereas Wednesday provided resistance, with Thursday sitting between the two.

To be honest, I didn't really love this show as it went on and I kind of hated the storyline that led to this scene and the ending, but this was kind of a cute scene. Ring bear(er)? Enunciation is fun! https://youtu.be/43EnqRJob7k?si=fFHzIopoLz57A0YU
I liked it in general, but 15 A? Gimme a break.

Re: Friday's puzzle

SOLITARY: antisocial? 

I find this somewhat disturbing.
52A - I'm just saying...tildes matter.   : D
A droid, for short, is a BOT.  Everybody knows that.

Sorry, but what are the "duplicate entries?"

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️
So much fun cluing in this one. I really hit a good groove and ended up recording my fastest Friday time at sub-9-minutes with no lookups. Doing my best to 31-Across!

lots of fun and some very clever cluing. and my favorite cross is definitely 46D at 62A: maya angelou meets toni morrison! i would really love to be at THAT tea party! 

thanks. greg and glenn!
The metoo movement started in 2016, not 2006. Really had me stumped because the only thing I could think of from around the mid-oughts was the occupy Wall Street movement. Written by a man perhaps?

BOO!
A pox on variants!
Wretched ISOMERS of E and I

It GRIEVES me, but yon grid FORCED me to LASE this MENTALNOTE into my INERT pudding of a brain:
Both "ingrain" and "engrain" describe the process of making something a permanent and integral part of someone's character or mind. While "ingrain" is more commonly used, "engrain" is older, less common. 

Nay, good forum, twill do me no good to RANTAT Es and Is. 

Pray tell, what is this EMAILSPAM? 
By the saints! (OHBOY!)
You speak of morrows BUSINESSACUMEN?
BUSINESSACUMEN!
TUT TUT. 
Tis naught but SAD OMENS of "ACTIONITEM" and "ASOF" and "ALONGTHOSELINES" 

The gold PULSAR played, so I sheathe this dirk back in its scabbard neath mine TABARD* and ignore the SCENT from milord's STY.

*last appeated May 25, 2014 NYT grid
Why do you even put the tricky clues link if it’s broken every day? Do you even test it?

Lowest of the low would solve closer to something like bottom of the barrel, e.g the current US admin really scraped it… than what the solve is, for which a better clue would be far-fallen or fallen on hard times.

Still working on a lot due to those 3 tricky mid strata solves.
interesting that so many found this puzzle easy. I did not at all.

@Jonathan
And they snuck ANTE in there too!

@Marc
Yeah, that slowed me down a bit.
@Marc It's especially odd considering that only five days ago the exact same answer was clued as "Social movement of 2017."

@Shrike

Originated in 2006, became a major movement in 2017.
@Marc   Yeah, I had to double-check my thought on that.  Invented 2006, widespread usage 2017 or so.

Linda Jo,

Clueless emus.

Warren's post was on topic and spot on.
@DawnW same experience for me, but I'll take 'em when I can get 'em.

@DawnW

Of course this means nothing because I'm Polish but for me this was impossibly hard without lookups 🤷🏾

DawnW,

I hope it fights dirty.

@Marshall Walthew

I agree.  Beautiful voice, beautiful woman, and by all appearances, beautiful soul.
(It just occurred to me that I'm thinking of that song as I finish laundry and get ready to leave town to see family tomorrow. 🐇🐣✌🏻)

@Whoa Nellie I didn’t realize how many of her hit songs I knew and loved. Her Wikipedia entry is a joy to read. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marilyn_McCoo I bet she would be delighted to know she is in today’s NYT puzzle and see how many people still think kindly of her and appreciate her talent.

@Marshall Walthew

Nice tribute. I always liked the wry line, "One less man to pick up after  ... "

@Teresa

Great line, as is “one less egg to fry.”
@Steve L It's a double play

@Steve L
Could it be 17A with BARBIECORE and decor?

@Valerie

No, a dupe has to involve the exact same word, not just sound-alike elements.

@Steve L
As MikeW hinted, PLAY is the dupe in
PLAYACTION
and
PLAYITCOOL
@Grumpy Oh! Thanks for clearing that up. I was looking for it too and thought it might be LOB and LOBos, but those aren't the same words, so I was hoping I was wrong.
@Grumpy TIL that you weren't supposed to duplicate individual words (that are part of longer answers) in a crossword grid

@Grumpy   Thanks for the explanation of the "dupe" comment.  I couldn't find it either, because they are not duplicates.   One is from a gang turf fight in "West Side Story".  The other is from American football.    Calling them duplicates is not cool, and not my option.

@jennie

Snap!
@jennie the word PLAY is duplicated. Even though they appear within other phrases, that usually isn't allowed in an NYT xword puzzle.
@Phil C. And TIL that maybe it can be okay if they aren't actually the same word in the sense that one is a noun or adjective and another is a verb.

@MikeW

It's also a double IT, although maybe small words are permitted to be duplicates. I'll have to check with the IT department
@James yeah, unless im missing smth as well, it's just as in toe ring ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Can you please explain it to me some more?

The smarphone is a device designed around using the internet and multiple apps from multiple sources, which distinguishes it from PDAs.

(Remember the little green guy that was the logo & mascot when the 'Droid OS first came out? Somewhere I have a collectible doll from a conference way back when...)

To both you and @Nora, I'd add that what separated PDA devices from smartphones* really is that the former were not designed for the transmission of data over the air. Palm Pilots and *early* Blackberries fall into this category. 

*However, there were plenty of devices the industry called smartphones before the iPhone became the first *modern* smartphone. Remember the Symbian OS? Nokia dominance? Flash-based mobile apps? I had an HTC Startrek in 2007 that ran Windows Mobile. And "multiple sources" created apps for these devices -- I know I did!

Even before Apple released the first iPhone SDK (developer kit), the distinction between it and earlier smartphones was the move to a fullsize touchscreen -- and away from a physical keyboard. That Windows device I had used T9 "shortcuts" to facilitate typing on the 9-key keypad-! 

Thanks for a fun trip down memory lane -- poor clue notwithstanding!

@Ingrid

A bit of etymology here, pretty widely known but fun to discover if you've never encountered it:

Public areas set aside for the display of plants and animals from around the world were once referred to as botanical gardens and zoological gardens, respectively. The former term is still widely used, but the latter got shortened to "zoos,"  in the nineteenth century, and has pretty much supplanted "zoological gardens."

I could try referring to Atlanta's botanical garden as "the bot," I guess, but I don't think it would catch on.

@Heidi (Part 2)  Back to Asbestos and Talc... So there was some asbestos mixed with talc.   Which creates a problem for  personal care manufacturers.  The were using talc for lots of things.  SPECIFICALLY on feminine protection products.

This led to asbestos being found in the reproductive system of women who used products with talc...and it leads to a conversation about ovarian cancer.

Here's where it gets tricky and interesting...

1)Many women using talc laden products may already have had co-morbidities which lead to health problems such as ovarian cancer...such as extra weight.

2)Memory is fuzzy...so people when asked if they used talc in feminine products may have been using corn starch and not talc

3)Ovarian cancer is pretty rare...so it may be impossible to determine if asbestos in the reproductive system led to the tiny increase in cancer reported.

So that's where we are on that.

BUT if asbestos does pose a risk to mucous membranes....Would you want it in your digestive system?  Would you want it to touch the walls of your mouth?  Or does mixing it with gum make it non-friable and perfectly safe.

@Bruce oh...i'm not arguing in favor of talc in food (as you can see in part 2)

I'm just discussing the perceived risk of asbestos vs the actual risk.

There is a giant industry which makes money off of asbestos...where the typical person doesnt have much risk at all.

When they test a building for asbestos they are comparing the inside air with the outside air.  They arent testing to see no asbestos at all.  We breathe asbestos every day since its a natural fiber in rocks...and it gets into the air.   And frankly...we have been exposed for decades in things like car and truck brake pads...despite asbestos being "banned".

Its the same story with black mold.   Black mold is also natural in the air...and when they test for it in a house...they compare it to outside air to see if its a safe level...They arent testing for it to not be there at all.   The people most at risk from black mold are people who are allergic to penicillin...They are most likely to have an allergic reaction.

There are a bunch of legal industries which are based on fear and panic...Which out sizes the actual risk from the exposure.

And once again...I dont believe we should have asbestos in our food...or black mold in our homes...Just that we need to keep perspective on the actual risk.

@Paul
My dad built our house outside of Atlanta after WWII...and finished it with asbestos "shingles" on the outside.  These had to be sawn to size, and even though it wasn't a large house, there were a lot of them.  (In photos, I'm the baby standing in the playpen; my older sister has a shovel and is posing (but not really working.)  These shingles were considered an improved safety product at the time (1948...)  Both parents died of cancers in the early 2000's.  I don't think anyone tried to trace origins other than our dad's smoking, but our mother, her sister, AND their mother all died of lymphoma.  (I wonder about the water in Smyrna GA in the 1920's...)

@Mean Old Lady

I used to work in Morton Hall in the campus of the University of Alabama in Huntsville. The building went up in the 1950s.

They discovered that asbestos had been used in the construction of the room I worked in on a daily basis. We were all ordered out on very short notice, the place was sealed up and an airlock installed, and a crew of men in head-to-toe sealed suits with plexiglass visors and trailing hoses supplying filtered air spent several days tearing it all out.

One of them emerged, still suited up, saw me standing outside and walked up, with the air compressor rattling in the background.

"Did you work in there?" he asked.

"Yeah, I did," I responded.

"How long were you exposed?"

Having that asked of you by someone who is essentially wearing a space suit is pretty chilling.

@Mean Old Lady That style of shingle is still called asbestos.... They dont have asbestos anymore.  But if you walked into a siding and roofing place and said "I need a pack of asbestos shingles"  They would ask you if you wanted smooth or wavy and then get you a pack.

LOB-- think tennis.
@Vaer ah, is that it? I know approximately zero about tennis, so that explains my lack of getting that one. Thanks!
Not sure about the tennis reference. That would be a "lob shot", not a "lob hit", wouldn't it? Or is that British English usage?
@Oikofuge Hmm...  Seems like a dubiously phrased 'one' to me, still. But it makes more sense than it did a minute ago. Thanks

@Oikofuge
In other words, the clue would still seem to be about something that happens before a "smash hit", rather than a "hit" that happens before a "smash".

@Oikofuge. Simply put, in tennis, if your opponent is at the net to volley, i.e. to hit the ball before it bounces, you may elect to LOB the ball over his/her head in order to thwart their intentions. Your opponent, in turn, may have anticipated this and may run back to position for a SMASH HIT, which is like an overhead shot, generally.

@Oikofuge 

I think we call it "estate law." No "s."

@Loopy

Yes, I get all that. But @Tony's original point was about the *hyphenation*. In tennis, as in baseball, the LOB happens (as you say) before a "smash hit", rather than being a kind of hit which happens before a smash. 
So [Pre-smash hit] is an awkward construction, that doesn't quite say what's required, which is why @Tony proposed "[Pre smash-hit"].

It's a classic hyphenation issue, with which subeditors and style books have wrestled for years. I think it's interesting, but I'm getting a sense I might be alone in that ...

[And, to be clear, while it made me raise a passing eyebrow at the punctuation, I have no objection to the clue as it stands.]

Oikofuge,

I would call almost any direction of the tennis ball by the racquet a hit or a shot. A lob is a shot or a hit. So is a smash. So is a volley. Often, a lob is a hit that happens prior to a smash. Thus the clue: it’s a pre-smash hit. I personally would never identify a shot as a “volley hit” or a “smash hit” or a “lob hit” (hyphenated or otherwise).

@Dave Apophenia... or patternicity....  

Looking for meaningful patterns in unrelated things.

Sometimes when I pay at a store...It comes out to an even number $6.00   or $15.00 whatever....And its always a nice moment in a world of OCD.

And then I say to myself...."I would think it would be a round number 1% of the time".   

But I bet it really isnt 1 in 100 and there is a MIT math major who has proved that....Proved that the numbers really arent random because of how pricing is set and ends with specific numbers... How the average number of items a customer buys affects the results.   And probably the weather and whether or not its raining.

@Barry Ancona

I was about to argue with you, but I finally understand what you mean by "it is a clue."

In crosswords, I always thought the clues were basically definitions.

I finally see that they are pointers that are pointing us in a direction towards a goal or an end. This would be the usage of the word "clue" in the realm of mysteries and crime solving.

Given that understanding, I would agree that any crossword clue, however inaccurate, is valid.

But I will admit that some clues have ticked me off over the years.

@Lula A "?" often means something down the direction of a pun.

Because of television history "Leave it to Beaver"   can be taken as a single thought.... Which is why we have that phrase at all...I mean "leave it to beaver" truly doesnt make any sense in regular English.

And then the pun.  What would you leave up to a beaver?  ..a DAM.

So its not that we are truly waiting for a beaver to make a dam...its just a pun.

And...for those who are confused what a pun is...."I was always told "its a play on words"  which just adds confusion to the mix.  A pun really is something which exploits the different meanings of a word...or words which sound similar.
